PLQ (red): 48 seats; ADQ (blue): 41 seats; PQ (cyan): 36 seats. | title = Premier | before_election = [[Jean Charest]] | before_party = Quebec Liberal Party | after_election = [[Jean Charest]] | after_party = Quebec Liberal Party }} The '''Quebec general election of 2007''' was held in the [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[Quebec]] on March 26, 2007 to elect members of the [[38th National Assembly of Quebec]]. The [[Quebec Liberal Party]] led by [[Jean Charest]] managed to win a plurality of seats, but were reduced to a [[minority government]], Quebec's first in 129 years, since the [[Quebec general election, 1878|1878 general election]]. The [[Action dÃ©mocratique du QuÃ©bec]], in a major breakthrough, became the official [[opposition (parliamentary)|opposition]]. The [[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]] was relegated to third-party status for the first time since the [[Quebec general election, 1973|1973 election]]. The Liberals won their lowest share of the popular vote since [[Canadian confederation|Confederation]], and the PQ won their lowest share since 1973 and their second lowest ever.[http://www.assnat.qc.ca/fra/patrimoine/votes.html La rÃ©partition des voix aux Ã©lections gÃ©nÃ©rales]{{dead link|date=February 2011}} Each of the three major parties won nearly one-third of the popular vote, easily the closest three-way split in Quebec electoral history. Voter turnout among those eligible was 71.23%, a marginal difference from the [[Quebec general election, 2003|previous general election in 2003]].{{Cite news| author = LCN | title = Un taux de participation de 71% | url = http://lcn.canoe.com/lcn/infos/ national/quebec2007/archives/2007/03/20070327-004949.html | date = March 27, 2007}}{{Cite news| author = CTV News | title = Que. Liberals win minority, ADQ forms opposition | publisher = CTV | url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070325/quebec_election_070326/20070327/ | date = March 27, 2007 }} This was the first time since the 1970s that a government was not returned for its second term with a majority. ==Overview== With just over a year left in the government's five year mandate, the Liberals called an election for March 26, 2007. In August 2006, there were widespread rumours of an election to be held in the fall with speculation that [[Premier of Quebec|Premier]] [[Jean Charest]] wanted to hold elections before a [[40th Canadian federal election|federal election]] would be held. [[BenoÃ®t Pelletier]], the minister responsible for electoral reform, had announced his plan to [[table (verb)|table]] two bills about election reform during the fall, possibly leading to a [[referendum]] on [[voting system]] reform to be held concurrently with the election.{{cite web|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/Politique/2006/09/29/001-scrutin-referendum-qc.shtml |title=Mode de scrutin : Un rÃ©fÃ©rendum envisagÃ© au QuÃ©bec | Politique |publisher=Radio-Canada.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} However, as of December 2006, this plan has been put off indefinitely due to strong resistance to the idea of proportional representation from within the Liberal Party.[http://www.cyberpresse.ca/article/20061213/CPACTUALITES/61213157/1026/CPACTUALITES Le gouvernement Charest repousse la rÃ©forme du mode de scrutin | ActualitÃ©s | Cyberpresse] Speculation grew that a provincial election would be held following the federal budget. It was thought that the federal [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative]] government would present a budget that would address the perceived [[fiscal imbalance in Canada|fiscal imbalance]]. This measure would help Charest argue that his government was more effective in getting concessions from the federal government than a PQ government would be. With polls showing Charest's Liberals ahead of the opposition for the first time in several years, speculation intensified that Charest would not wait until the federal budget to call a provincial election but call one in the winter to take advantage of both of these developments. Charest recalled the legislature early in order to table a provincial budget on February 20, 2007. On the same day, federal [[Minister of Finance (Canada)|Minister of Finance]] [[Jim Flaherty]] announced that the federal budget would be tabled on March 19, clearing the way for Charest to set a provincial election for a week later in hopes of benefiting from Flaherty's budget. On February 21, Charest called the election for March 26. ===Issues=== Charest wants to negotiate a solution to the problem of the [[Fiscal imbalance in Canada|fiscal imbalance]] between the federal and provincial governments with [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]]. [[AndrÃ© Boisclair]], leader of the [[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]], had said he would hold a referendum (or "popular consultation", as in the party platform) on the issue of Quebec independence as soon as possible after an election win.[http://www.cyberpresse.ca/article/20060324/CPACTUALITES/60324099/5032/CPACTUALITES Jocelyne Richer : Boisclair veut un rÃ©fÃ©rendum le plus tÃ´t possible | ActualitÃ©s | Cyberpresse] [[Multiculturalism]], [[laÃ¯citÃ©|secularism]] and the place of cultural and religious minorities in Quebec were issues in this election. There was a large scale debate over "[[reasonable accommodation]]" towards cultural minorities, and a few political leaders expressed their views on the question. [[Mario Dumont]], leader of the [[Action dÃ©mocratique du QuÃ©bec|Action dÃ©mocratique]], took a clearer position on the question than the others, calling on the majority to protect some elements of national identity and values such as [[gender equality]], and suggesting that a Quebec [[Constitution]] be written, in which the privileges cultural minorities are to be given would be clarified.{{cite web|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/Politique/2007/01/16/006-dumont-accommodement.shtml |title=Accommodements raisonnables : Dumont veut une constitution | Politique |publisher=Radio-Canada.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} ==Timeline== *[[2005 in Canada|2005]] **November 15 - [[AndrÃ© Boisclair]] is [[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois leadership election, 2005|elected as leader of the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]] with 53.7% of the vote from party members. **December 12 - Two [[by-election]]s are held. The election of [[Raymond Bachand]] allows the [[Quebec Liberal Party|Liberals]] to keep the riding of [[Outremont (provincial electoral district)|Outremont]], while former [[Bloc QuÃ©bÃ©cois]] MP [[StÃ©phane Bergeron]] wins [[VerchÃ¨res (provincial electoral district)|VerchÃ¨res]], [[Bernard Landry]]'s former riding, for the [[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]]. *[[2006 in Canada|2006]] **February 4 - [[QuÃ©bec solidaire]], a new [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] party, is formed from the merger of the [[Union des forces progressistes]] party and the [[Option citoyenne]] political movement. **February 28 - Raymond Bachand enters [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] as Minister of Economic Development, Innovation and Export Trade. In this same [[cabinet shuffle]], [[Thomas Mulcair]] loses the job of Environment minister to [[Claude BÃ©chard]]. Some [[Pundit (politics)|pundits]] speculate that Mulcair was punished for his opposition to the [[Mont Orford]] condo development project. **April 10 - The Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois keeps the riding of [[Sainte-MarieâSaint-Jacques (provincial electoral district)|Sainte-MarieâSaint-Jacques]] in a by-election. [[Martin Lemay]] is elected with 41.2% of the vote. Notably, [[Manon MassÃ©]], the candidate from QuÃ©bec solidaire, finishes third with 22.2% of the vote in this working-class district, while the [[Action dÃ©mocratique du QuÃ©bec|Action dÃ©mocratique]] only gets 1.9% of the vote, down from 8.3% in the [[Quebec general election, 2003|2003 general election]]. **August 14 - By-elections are held in [[Pointe-aux-Trembles (electoral district)|Pointe-aux-Trembles]] and [[Taillon]]. AndrÃ© Boisclair is unsurprisingly and easily elected in Pointe-aux-Trembles, the Liberals and Action dÃ©mocratique having declined to field candidates against him. The Greens place second with 12% and QuÃ©bec solidaire, third with 8%. [[Marie Malavoy]] of the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois is elected in Taillon. **August 22 - Boisclair and Malavoy are sworn in as members of the National Assembly. Boisclair becomes [[Leader of the Official Opposition (Quebec)|opposition leader]]. **October 17 - The fall session of the National Assembly starts, with the current crisis in Quebec's forestry industry as the most important issue. **November 27 - In a vote of 266 to 16, The [[Canadian House of Commons]] voted to recognise [[French-speaking Quebecer|QuÃ©bÃ©cois]] as a [[nation]] within a unified Canada, once again putting the issue of independence in the spotlight. *[[2007 in Canada|2007]] **January 19 - Radio-Canada reveals that Pierre Descoteaux, Liberal member from [[Groulx]], almost [[crossing the floor|crossed the floor]] to the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois during the fall 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/Politique/2007/01/19/002-descoteaux-pq.shtml |title=Parti libÃ©ral du QuÃ©bec : La tentation souverainiste | Politique |publisher=Radio-Canada.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} **January 22 - During a visit to [[France]], AndrÃ© Boisclair meets [[SÃ©golÃ¨ne Royal]], [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist]] candidate for the [[French presidential election, 2007|2007 presidential election]]. At this occasion, Royal expresses her support for the "liberty and sovereignty" of Quebec.{{cite web|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/Politique/2007/01/22/002-royal-souverainete-boisclair.shtml |title=Parti quÃ©bÃ©cois : Royal appuie la souverainetÃ© du QuÃ©bec | Politique |publisher=Radio-Canada.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} After being criticized by several French media and French and Canadian politicians, such as [[Prime Minister of Canada|prime minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] and [[Leader of the Opposition (Canada)|opposition leader]] [[StÃ©phane Dion]], Royal clarifies her thought by saying that she was not interfering in Canadian internal affairs or trying to dictate Quebec's policy, but that the future of Quebec will have to be decided by Quebecers.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2007/01/23/france-royal.html | work=CBC News | title=French politician defends Quebec comments | date=January 23, 2007}} **February 14 - [[Pierre Arcand]], former president of Corus and presumed Liberal candidate in [[Mont-Royal (provincial electoral district)|Mont-Royal]], expresses his displeasure with Action dÃ©mocratique leader [[Mario Dumont]] by comparing him with [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]]. In response, Dumont threatens legal action but Arcand refuses to apologize. [[Premier of Quebec|Premier]] [[Jean Charest]] stands by his candidate, and is called a "little partisan premier" by Dumont.{{cite web|url=http://www.ledevoir.com/2007/02/16/131352.html |title=Pierre Arcand refuse de se Â«mettre Ã  genouxÂ» devant Mario Dumont |publisher=Ledevoir.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} **February 20 - Finance minister [[Michel Audet]] tables a budget. Among other measures, this budget promises income tax reductions of 250 million dollars and allocates new sums of money to the health and education systems, as well as to the maintenance of roads and bridges. Spending is also increased for the protection of the environment and for the regions' economic development.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2007/02/20/qc-quebecbudget20070220.html | work=CBC News | title=Tax cuts, health spending in Quebec pre-election budget | date=February 20, 2007}} **February 21 - [[Premier of Quebec|Premier]] [[Jean Charest]] calls a general election for March 26.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/quebecvotes2007/story/2007/02/21/charest-election-070221.html?ref=rss | work=CBC News | title=Quebec election set for March 26 | date=February 21, 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070221.wquecharest0221/BNStory/National/home |title=National |publisher=globeandmail.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}} **March 1 - Radio DJ [[Louis Champagne]] of [[Saguenay, Quebec|Saguenay]] creates a controversy by attacking AndrÃ© Boisclair and the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois candidate in Saguenay, [[Sylvain Gaudreault]], over their homosexuality, saying that the factory workers of [[JonquiÃ¨re]] would never vote for gays. He also says the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois is like a "club of fags". (Gaudreault went on to win the riding.) Boisclair responds that Champagne's remarks are insulting towards the people of Saguenay. Premier Charest and Action dÃ©mocratique leader Dumont also condemn the attacks. Champagne is later suspended from his job and has to apologize. **March 4 - [[Jean-FranÃ§ois Plante]], the Action dÃ©mocratique candidate in [[Deux-Montagnes (provincial electoral district)|Deux-Montagnes]], makes controversial comments about women on his blog. Among other things, he questions the provincial government's policies of affirmative action for women and of wage equity between traditionally masculine and feminine occupations, claiming that they lead to discrimination against men. He retracts his comments on the next day, but also accuses AndrÃ© Boisclair of "playing" his homosexuality when it helps him. As a result, he is forced to withdraw his candidacy on March 8. He is replaced as ADQ candidate in Deux-Montagnes by [[Lucie Leblanc]]. **March 6 - Premier Jean Charest brings the issue of Quebec independence at the forefront of the campaign by saying, while speaking with an English-language journalist, that he does not believe that in the case of separation, Quebec would necessarily keep its territorial integrity. Charest later claims that what he had actually wanted to say was that Quebec was indivisible, but his opponents recall comments he had made in [[1996 in Canada|1996]], while he was the leader of the federal [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservatives]], to the effect that in the case of a "yes" result in the [[Quebec referendum, 1995|1995 referendum]], the [[Cree]] and [[Inuit]] would have had a good legal basis on which to declare independence from Quebec. **March 8 - Newspaper [[La Presse (Canada)|''La Presse'']] publishes an article claiming that in a 2003 book, [[Robin Philpot]], Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois candidate in [[Saint-HenriâSainte-Anne (provincial electoral district)|Saint-HenriâSainte-Anne]], had denied that a [[Rwandan Genocide|genocide]] had taken place in [[Rwanda]] in 1994. Philpot later says that he had not denied that massacres had taken place, but that he wanted people to remember that they had been committed by all parties to the conflict. AndrÃ© Boisclair says that he is "hurt" by his candidate's comments and reminds that the existence of the Rwandan genocide is not in question. **March 13 - The [[leaders debate]] took place in [[Quebec City]]. The Liberals, the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois and the Action dÃ©mocratique du QuÃ©bec took part but QuÃ©bec solidaire and the Green party were not invited to participate. **March 19 - The federal government releases a budget which gives Quebec 2.3 billion dollars. **March 23 - There is widespread outcry when poll clerks are instructed on how to let women wearing the [[niqÄb]], an Islamic face veil, vote. After the longstanding policy was criticized by all three main parties, the chief electoral officer reversed his decision and stated that all voters would have to show their face, but not before being inundated by complaints from people opposed to this form of [[reasonable accommodation]] for the immigrant population. Meanwhile, women who actually wear the niqÄb say they were never opposed to showing their face when voting.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/quebecvotes2007/story/2007/03/23/qc-niqab20070323.html?ref=rss | work=CBC News | title=Muslim women will have to lift veils to vote in Quebec election | date=March 23, 2007}} **March 26 - Election date. ==Major parties== *[[Action dÃ©mocratique du QuÃ©bec]] *[[Quebec Liberal Party]] *[[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]] *[[Green Party of Quebec]] *[[QuÃ©bec solidaire]] ==Results==
